utterances: (Soundbite of applause)

Bruce Hornsby and his band, here live in Studio 4A.

I have to say that took a turn I wasn't expecting there.
Yeah, me neither.
We've never done it quite that way, had we?
Okay, so how does that work, when you just sort of -
We're just going with what's happening, just listening, just using our ears, and just reacting to what other people are doing, and that's really all it is.
It's just really playing music.
It's not a pop music or rock music aesthetic.
It's totally coming from improvised music or jazz music.

But that's - a lot of us are coming from that background, so we're well-versed in winging it and listening to what people are doing and, you know, using something that they do for the next section, the next bit.
There's some eye contact going on, too, I think, right?
Oh, always.
I mean, you're kind of looking at each other and trying to figure where the next -

Can you believe he did that - sort of thing.
Oh now, that's what he's doing.
Okay, well let's do that.
That sort of thing.

Hi, Paul.
Yeah, hi.
My question is related to your last comment.

On the portions of the song where you're not the instrumentalist, for instance if there's a guitar solo or a solo for wind, do your band members write those portions of the songs or collaborate with you as the songwriter on those parts of the song, or do you write those portions of it yourself?
Did they do what?
I missed it.
Did they write something?
What did he say?
Do they write part of the song -
Do they collaborate with you in writing the music, the notes in the song?
The notes that they're playing?
Yes.
No.
What they're playing is improvised, it's totally improvised.
They would do it differently every time.
I think they would.
I would hope they would.
No, it's not written at all.
It's just a basic chordal framework coming from the song that I've written that dictates what they're going to solo over, but no, it's not written at all.
Would that be true of the album version, as well, on these songs?
Well, yes.
Yeah, the only difference would be is sometimes they will come in and over-dub over a track that's already existing, so - but no, actually it's the same approach, it's the same thing.
Oh, I see.
Well, thank you.
Well thank you, Paulie.
Paulie from Sacramento.
Thanks for your call, Paul.
Thanks, Paul.
And an email here saying "I've seen Bruce play with the Grateful Dead, I've seen him play Dead songs with his own band.
Now I'm just a fan, but it seems to me that Bruce really gets their songs more than most musicians.
So can you speak to your kinship with the Dead and the time you played with them?
Well, I can only say that I get it in the way that I love it.
I love their songwriting.
I think they're underrated, they're underappreciated as songwriters.
I think they have fully 50 great songs.
Lots of songs of theirs sound like old folk songs that could've been written 100 years ago.
So that's how I get it.
I just get it because I love it, and so that' just a simple answer.
It's got to be a simple answer, because we're going to run out of time to play this song.
I was going to say, do you think you can play this song in the -
It's going to be hard.
I'm going to play a short version of it.
Okay.

Thanks to Bruce Hornsby, to his band, and to his crew for making all of this possible today here in Studio 4A.
Scientists have created a device from living tissue that can mimic the female reproductive cycle.
They hope their creation will help them find new treatments for medical problems that affect many women.
NPR health correspondent Rob Stein has details.
The female reproductive system is complicated and hard to study.
So a team of scientists decided to make something they hoped would help.
Well, we call this EVATAR.
Teresa Woodruff is a scientist at Northwestern University.
So we use the EVATAR basically as a play on the avatar.
So an avatar is kind of a digital representation of an individual in a virtual environment.
And so when we thought about this synthetic version of the female reproductive track, we thought about the word EVATAR.
But the synthetic version of the female reproductive tract isn't digital; it's made from real living tissue.
We have human fallopian tube, human uterus, human cervix.
That was donated for research by women who had them surgically removed for some reason.
In the EVATAR, the scientists connect the living tissue with mouse ovaries.
Each organ is in a separate plastic cube.

We have a system that allows each of the organs to have a cube, basically, a area within almost a handheld device that allows the tissues to interact with the other tissues that are in neighboring cubes.
And can recreate the complex cascade of hormones that occurs during a woman's normal monthly cycle.
We were able to recapitulate the full menstrual cycle, a complete menstrual cycle, a 28-day cycle in this platform.
That even resulted in the ovaries producing an egg.
So why are they doing this?
